ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hyperacusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Evidenced by significantly reduced Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs) ranging from 70–76 dB HL and reported sensitivity to environmental sounds.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Subjective Tinnitus
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient reports constant bilateral high-pitched ringing/buzzing; TRQ score of 40 indicates clinically significant distress.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sound-triggered Headaches
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Severe daily headaches triggered by specific sounds and electrical emissions, correlated with hyperacusis symptoms.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and rule out hearing loss.
To assess speech recognition thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To quantify sound tolerance and diagnose hyperacusis.
To establish baseline awareness and disturbance levels.
To measure the psychological impact and distress caused by tinnitus.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient has normal hearing sensitivity and middle ear function. However, she presents with significant hyperacusis as indicated by reduced LDLs (70-76 dB HL) and severe tinnitus distress (TRQ 40), with symptoms heavily linked to environmental sounds and headaches.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Pure-tone thresholds were within normal limits bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Speech recognition thresholds (SRTs) and word recognition scores (WRSs) were normal.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs)
tests.result_summary: Significantly reduced bilaterally (70–76 dB HL across 500-4000 Hz), indicating hyperacusis.

tests.name: Subjective Tinnitus Ratings
tests.result_summary: 100% awareness and 80% disturbance during awake time in the past week.

tests.name: Tinnitus Reaction Questionnaire (TRQ)
tests.result_summary: Total score 40, indicating clinically significant distress. Question 24 (suicide) score was 0.

proposed_items: Sound therapy using white or pink noise to desensitize the auditory system.
Initial trial with a Personal Listening Device (PLD) followed by custom in-the-ear (ITE) sound generators.
Protocol: Wear devices for at least 8 hours/day, gradually increasing output to a comfortable listening level (CLL).
Coordination with neurologist to monitor and reduce headache medications once acclimated to sound therapy.
counseling_actions: Explain neurophysiological principles of tinnitus and hyperacusis (increased central gain).
Discuss the 'vicious cycle' of negative emotional reaction and attention exacerbating symptoms.
Advise against overuse of hearing protection (earplugs) in quiet environments.
Provide recommended reading: 'Consumer Handbook on Tinnitus' by Richard S. Tyler.

escalation.rationale_short: Proceed with sound therapy fitting and management; no immediate medical red flags (MRI normal, no suicidal ideation).

follow_up_plan.timeline: 2 weeks following the fitting of sound generators
follow_up_plan.objective: To monitor progress and ensure sound generators do not exacerbate headaches.

expected_outcome: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs) at 11 months: Improved to >90 dB HL bilaterally (Right: 96, 96, 94, 98 dB HL; Left: 94, 96, 92, 96 dB HL at 500, 1000, 2000, 4000 Hz).
Tinnitus Reaction Questionnaire (TRQ) at 11 months: Total score reduced to 3, indicating no significant disturbance.
Subjective Tinnitus Ratings at 11 months: Awareness reduced to 10% and disturbance reduced to 5% of awake time.
Patient reported cessation of headache medications and that tinnitus no longer interferes with sleep.
